roc_curve(training_data, validation_data, coefficients=None, bias=None, learning_rate=0.0001, positive_label=None, negative_label=None, max_iter=100, seed=42, norm='yes', num_iter=10, lower_bound=0.4, upper_bound=0.6)[source]

Generate Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curves and calculate Area Under the Curve (AUC) values.

Parameters:

  • training_data – Training data for logistic regression.

  • validation_data – Validation data for generating ROC curves.

  • coefficients – Initial coefficients for logistic regression (if None, they will be initialized).

  • bias – Initial bias for logistic regression (if None, it will be initialized).

  • learning_rate – Learning rate for logistic regression.

  • positive_label – Specify the positive label (default is the first unique label in data).

  • negative_label – Specify the negative label (default is the second unique label in data).

  • max_iter – Maximum number of iterations for logistic regression.

  • seed –

  • norm – Should the data before training process be normalized.

  • num_iter – Number of threshold values for ROC curve.

  • lower_bound – Lower bound for ROC curve threshold.

  • upper_bound – Upper bound for ROC curve threshold.

Returns:

List of ROC curve data as tuples (threshold, AUC).

smartsolve.models module

class smartsolve.models.DecisionTree(train_data, min_points=2, max_depth=10, num_features=None, curr_depth=0)[source]

Bases: object

A Decision Tree classifier for binary classification problems.

Parameters:

  • train_data – The training data.

  • min_points – The minimum number of data points required to split a node (default is 2).

  • max_depth – The maximum depth of the decision tree (default is 10).

  • num_features – The number of random features to consider for each split (default is None).

  • curr_depth – The current depth of the tree while building (default is 0).

labels – The labels for which to find the most common label.

Returns:

The most common label.

  • labels – The labels of the data.

The best feature and threshold for splitting.

class smartsolve.models.GradientBoosting(train_data, min_points=2, max_depth=2, num_features=None, num_trees=10, curr_depth=0, threshold=0.5)[source]

Bases: object

A gradient boosting classifier.

Args: train_data (list): Training data in the form [(label, features), …]. min_points (int): Minimum number of data points for a node (default is 2). max_depth (int): Maximum depth of decision trees (default is 2). num_features (int): Number of features to consider for each tree (default is None). num_trees (int): Number of boosting iterations (default is 10). curr_depth (int): Current depth during training (default is 0). threshold (float): Classification threshold (default is 0.5).

predict(features)[source]

Make predictions using the trained gradient boosting classifier.

Args: features (list): List of feature vectors for prediction.

Returns: numpy.ndarray: Predicted labels (0 or 1) for each input feature vector.

train()[source]

Train the gradient boosting classifier.

Parameters:

  • data – The dataset.

  • num_cluster – The number of clusters.

  • cluster – The cluster assignments for each data point.

Returns:

An array of updated cluster centroids.

  • data – The dataset to cluster.

  • num_cluster – The number of clusters.

  • prev_centroids – The previous cluster centroids.

Returns:

An array of cluster assignments.

class smartsolve.models.KNearestNeighbors(train_data, num_neighbors=5, distance='EU', algorithm='classification', p_value=2)[source]

Bases: object

K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) algorithm for classification and regression.

Parameters:

  • train_data (list) – The training data in the format [(y1,[x11,x12,…,x1n]), …].

  • num_neighbors (int) – The number of neighbors to consider (default is 5).

  • distance (str) – The distance metric to use (‘EU’, ‘MA, ‘MI’, ‘CH’, or ‘CO’).

  • algorithm (str) – The type of task (‘classification’ or ‘regression’).

  • p_value (int) – The p-value for the Minkowski distance (default is 2).

features

The features of the training data.

Type:

numpy.ndarray

labels

The labels of the training data.

Type:

numpy.ndarray

Fit the model to the training data.

  • k_singular_matrix (numpy.ndarray) – Reduced singular values as a diagonal matrix.

  • k_right_singular_vectors (numpy.ndarray) – Reduced transpose of right singular vectors.

Returns:

Reconstructed matrix.

Return type:

reconstructed_matrix (numpy.ndarray)

t_matrix

Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) for dimensionality reduction.

Parameters:

  • data (list or numpy.ndarray) – Input data in the form of a nested list or a numpy array.

  • num_dimension (int) – Number of dimensions to return after processing the input data.

data

The input matrix, which can be a nested list or a numpy array.

num_dimension

The number of dimensions to return after processing the input data.

U

The left singular vectors.

S

The singular values.

Vt

The transpose of the right singular vectors.

variance

Proportion of total variance explained.

t_matrix

Transformed matrix with reduced dimensions.

transform()[source]

Perform dimensionality reduction and reconstruction in a single step.

Returns:

Transformed matrix with reduced dimensions.

Return type:

reconstructed_matrix (numpy.ndarray)

  • num_dimension (int) – Number of dimensions to consider.

class smartsolve.models.SupportVectorMachines(training_data, optimization_algorithm='GD', kernel='linear', learning_rate=0.0001, lam=0.0001, max_iteration=1000, threshold=1e-05, regularization_parameter=1, epsilon=0.0001, sigma=- 0.1)[source]

Bases: object

Support Vector Machines (SVM) classifier.

Parameters: - training_data: List of training data points in the form [(y, [x1, x2, …, xn]), …]. - optimization_algorithm: Optimization algorithm to use (‘GD’ for Gradient Descent,

‘SMO’ for Sequential Minimal Optimization).

  • kernel: Kernel function to use (‘linear’, ‘quadratic’, ‘gaussian’).

  • learning_rate: Learning rate for GD (default is 1e-4).

  • lam: Regularization parameter (default is 1e-4).

  • max_iteration: Maximum number of iterations for training (default is 1000).

  • threshold: Convergence threshold for GD (default is 1e-5).

  • regularization_parameter: Regularization parameter for SMO (default is 1).

  • epsilon: Convergence tolerance for SMO (default is 1e-4).

  • sigma: Sigma value for the Gaussian kernel (default is -0.1).

The training_data must have the structure: [(y1, [x11, x12, …, x1n]), (y2, [x21, x22, x2n]), …, (ym, [xm1, xm2, …, xmn])]

Methods: - train: Train the SVM model using the selected optimization algorithm. - predict: Make predictions on input data points after training.

Note: Call the ‘train’ method before making predictions.

train()[source]

Train the Support Vector Machines (SVM) model using the specified optimization algorithm.

This method iteratively updates the weights and bias to find the optimal decision boundary.

Returns: None

class smartsolve.preprocessing.CategoricalData[source]

Bases: object

bin_encoding(data, labels=None, nums=None, index=1)[source]

Binary Encoding: Represents each category with binary code, combining label and one-hot encoding. Efficient for high-cardinality features.

Parameters:

  • data – Input DataFrame containing categorical data.

  • labels – Optional custom labels to use for encoding.

  • nums – Optional binary encoding values for labels.

  • index – Optional custom index to start binary encoding from.

Returns:

DataFrame with binary encoded categorical data.

count_encoding(data)[source]

Count Encoding: Replaces each category with its occurrence count in the dataset. Captures category prevalence information.

Parameters:

data – Input DataFrame containing categorical data.

Returns:

DataFrame with count-encoded categorical data.

freq_encoding(data, r=2)[source]

Frequency Encoding: Replaces categories with their frequency in the dataset. Suitable for nominal categorical features.

Parameters:

  • data – Input DataFrame containing categorical data.

  • r – Number of decimal places to round the frequency values.

Returns:

DataFrame with frequency-encoded categorical data.

l_encoding(data, labels=None, nums=None, index=1)[source]

Label Encoding: Assigns a unique integer to each category. Suitable for ordinal categorical variables with a meaningful order.

Parameters:

  • data – Input DataFrame containing categorical data.

  • labels – Optional custom labels to use for encoding.

  • nums – Optional list of integers to use for encoding.

  • index – Optional custom index to start numbering from.

Returns:

DataFrame with label-encoded categorical data.

mean_encoding(data, target=None)[source]

Mean Encoding (Target Encoding): Replaces categories with the mean of the target variable for that category. Captures feature-target relationship.

Parameters:

  • data – Input DataFrame containing categorical data.

  • target – Optional target variable for encoding. If not provided, unique target values from the data will be used.

Returns:

DataFrame with target-encoded categorical data.

onehot_encoding(data, yes=None, no=None)[source]

One-Hot Encoding: Creates binary columns for each category. Suitable for nominal categorical variables without a meaningful order.

Parameters:

  • data – Input DataFrame containing categorical data.

  • yes – Value to use for encoding category presence (default: 1).

  • no – Value to use for encoding absence of category (default: 0).

Returns:

DataFrame with one-hot encoded categorical data.

class smartsolve.preprocessing.FeatureScaling[source]

Bases: object

In this class, there are 9 different normalization methods for numeric data:

  1. Min-max scaling

  2. Standardization (Z-score normalization)

  3. Robust scaling

  4. Max-Absolute scaling

  5. Power transformation

  6. Unit Vector Scaling (L2 Normalization)

  7. Log transformation

  8. Box-Cox transformation

  9. Yeo-Johnson transformation

abs_max(data, columns=None)[source]

Max-Absolute scaling.

Parameters:

  • data – Input DataFrame containing numeric data.

  • columns – List of columns to scale using Max-Absolute scaling. If None, all numeric columns are selected.

Returns:

DataFrame with Max-Absolute scaled data.

Box-Cox transformation.

Parameters:

  • data – Input DataFrame containing numeric data.

  • lam – Lambda value for the Box-Cox transformation.

  • columns – List of columns to apply the Box-Cox transformation. If None, all numeric columns are selected.

Returns:

DataFrame with Box-Cox transformed data.

class smartsolve.preprocessing.MissingValue(data, replace='Mean', rep_value=None, rep_str='not defined')[source]

Bases: object

A class for handling missing values in a pandas DataFrame.

Parameters:

  • data – str or pandas.DataFrame The data source, which can be a file path to a CSV or a pandas DataFrame.

  • replace – str, optional The method to replace missing values. Default is ‘Mean’.

  • rep_value – str or numeric, optional The replacement value to use when ‘replace’ is ‘Value’. Default is None.

  • rep_str – str, optional The replacement string to use when ‘replace’ is ‘Str’. Default is ‘not defined’.

load_data():

Load the data source as a pandas DataFrame.

numerical():

Replace missing values in numeric columns using specified method.

qualitative():

Replace missing values in qualitative (categorical) columns using specified method.

load_data()[source]

Load the data source as a pandas DataFrame.

Returns:

pandas.DataFrame The loaded data as a DataFrame.

numerical()[source]

Replace missing values in numeric columns using the specified method.

Returns:

pandas.DataFrame The DataFrame with missing values replaced.

qualitative()[source]

Replace missing values in qualitative (categorical) columns using the specified method.

Returns:

pandas.DataFrame The DataFrame with missing values replaced.

class smartsolve.preprocessing.SelectFeature(csv_file=None, label=None)[source]

Bases: object

This class offers six methods to select the most suitable features for predicting the target:

  1. Correlation Selection

  2. Mutual Information

  3. Lasso Regularization

  4. Recursive Feature Elimination

  5. Select K Best

  6. Variance Threshold

Parameters:

  • csv_file (str) – The path to the CSV file containing the data.

  • label (str) – The name of the column in the data used as the label.

Select the best ‘k’ features based on their importance.

  • data_type (str) – The data type (‘numerical’ or ‘categorical’).

Returns:

A list of the best ‘k’ features.

Return type:

List[str]

class smartsolve.preprocessing.SplitData(data, method='Random', train=0.7, validation=None, test=0.2, date=None, num_folds=10)[source]

Bases: object

Splits input data into training, validation, and test sets using various methods.

Parameters:

  • data – Input data in the form of [(y1,[x11,x12,…,x1n]),(y2,[x21,x22,x2n]),…,(ym,[xm1,xm2,…,xmn])].

  • method – The splitting method to use (‘Random’, ‘Stratified’, ‘TimeSeries’, or ‘KFold’).

  • train – Fraction of data for training (default is 0.8).

  • validation – Fraction of data for validation (default is None).

  • test – Fraction of data for testing (default is 0.2).

  • date – List of date values for time series splitting (default is None).

  • num_folds – Number of folds for cross-validation (default is 10).

cross_validation()[source]

Perform K-fold cross-validation and split the data into training and test sets.

Returns:

Training, validation, and test data.

random()[source]

Randomly split the data into training, validation, and test sets.

Returns:

Training, validation, and test data.

stratified()[source]

Stratified split the data into training, validation, and test sets.

Returns:

Training, validation, and test data.

time_series()[source]

Split the data into training, validation, and test sets based on time series.

Returns:

Training, validation, and test data.

bin_encoding(data, labels=None, nums=None, index=1)[source]

Binary Encoding: Represents each category with binary code, combining label and one-hot encoding. Efficient for high-cardinality features.

Parameters:

  • data – Input DataFrame containing categorical data.

  • labels – Optional custom labels to use for encoding.

  • nums – Optional binary encoding values for labels.

  • index – Optional custom index to start binary encoding from.

Returns:

DataFrame with binary encoded categorical data.

class smartsolve.DecisionTree(train_data, min_points=2, max_depth=10, num_features=None, curr_depth=0)[source]

Bases: object

A Decision Tree classifier for binary classification problems.

Parameters:

  • train_data – The training data.

  • min_points – The minimum number of data points required to split a node (default is 2).

  • max_depth – The maximum depth of the decision tree (default is 10).

  • num_features – The number of random features to consider for each split (default is None).

  • curr_depth – The current depth of the tree while building (default is 0).

class smartsolve.GradientBoosting(train_data, min_points=2, max_depth=2, num_features=None, num_trees=10, curr_depth=0, threshold=0.5)[source]

Bases: object

A gradient boosting classifier.

Args: train_data (list): Training data in the form [(label, features), …]. min_points (int): Minimum number of data points for a node (default is 2). max_depth (int): Maximum depth of decision trees (default is 2). num_features (int): Number of features to consider for each tree (default is None). num_trees (int): Number of boosting iterations (default is 10). curr_depth (int): Current depth during training (default is 0). threshold (float): Classification threshold (default is 0.5).

predict(features)[source]

Make predictions using the trained gradient boosting classifier.

Args: features (list): List of feature vectors for prediction.

Returns: numpy.ndarray: Predicted labels (0 or 1) for each input feature vector.

train()[source]

Train the gradient boosting classifier.

class smartsolve.KNearestNeighbors(train_data, num_neighbors=5, distance='EU', algorithm='classification', p_value=2)[source]

Bases: object

K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) algorithm for classification and regression.

Parameters:

  • train_data (list) – The training data in the format [(y1,[x11,x12,…,x1n]), …].

  • num_neighbors (int) – The number of neighbors to consider (default is 5).

  • distance (str) – The distance metric to use (‘EU’, ‘MA, ‘MI’, ‘CH’, or ‘CO’).

  • algorithm (str) – The type of task (‘classification’ or ‘regression’).

  • p_value (int) – The p-value for the Minkowski distance (default is 2).

The features of the training data.

numpy.ndarray

Predicted labels.

class smartsolve.MissingValue(data, replace='Mean', rep_value=None, rep_str='not defined')[source]

Bases: object

A class for handling missing values in a pandas DataFrame.

Parameters:

  • data – str or pandas.DataFrame The data source, which can be a file path to a CSV or a pandas DataFrame.

  • replace – str, optional The method to replace missing values. Default is ‘Mean’.

  • rep_value – str or numeric, optional The replacement value to use when ‘replace’ is ‘Value’. Default is None.

  • rep_str – str, optional The replacement string to use when ‘replace’ is ‘Str’. Default is ‘not defined’.

load_data():

Load the data source as a pandas DataFrame.

numerical():

Replace missing values in numeric columns using specified method.

qualitative():

Replace missing values in qualitative (categorical) columns using specified method.

load_data()[source]

Load the data source as a pandas DataFrame.

Returns:

pandas.DataFrame The loaded data as a DataFrame.

numerical()[source]

Replace missing values in numeric columns using the specified method.

Returns:

pandas.DataFrame The DataFrame with missing values replaced.

qualitative()[source]

Replace missing values in qualitative (categorical) columns using the specified method.

Returns:

pandas.DataFrame The DataFrame with missing values replaced.

class smartsolve.SelectFeature(csv_file=None, label=None)[source]

Bases: object

This class offers six methods to select the most suitable features for predicting the target:

  1. Correlation Selection

  2. Mutual Information

  3. Lasso Regularization

  4. Recursive Feature Elimination

  5. Select K Best

  6. Variance Threshold

Parameters:

  • csv_file (str) – The path to the CSV file containing the data.

  • label (str) – The name of the column in the data used as the label.

Select the best ‘k’ features based on their importance.

Parameters:

  • k (int) – The number of best features to select.

  • data_type (str) – The data type (‘numerical’ or ‘categorical’).

Returns:

A list of the best ‘k’ features.

Return type:

List[str]

class smartsolve.SplitData(data, method='Random', train=0.7, validation=None, test=0.2, date=None, num_folds=10)[source]

Bases: object

Splits input data into training, validation, and test sets using various methods.

Parameters:

  • data – Input data in the form of [(y1,[x11,x12,…,x1n]),(y2,[x21,x22,x2n]),…,(ym,[xm1,xm2,…,xmn])].

  • method – The splitting method to use (‘Random’, ‘Stratified’, ‘TimeSeries’, or ‘KFold’).

  • train – Fraction of data for training (default is 0.8).

  • validation – Fraction of data for validation (default is None).

  • test – Fraction of data for testing (default is 0.2).

  • date – List of date values for time series splitting (default is None).

  • num_folds – Number of folds for cross-validation (default is 10).

cross_validation()[source]

Perform K-fold cross-validation and split the data into training and test sets.

Returns:

Training, validation, and test data.

random()[source]

Randomly split the data into training, validation, and test sets.

Returns:

Training, validation, and test data.

stratified()[source]

Stratified split the data into training, validation, and test sets.

Returns:

Training, validation, and test data.

time_series()[source]

Split the data into training, validation, and test sets based on time series.

Returns:

Training, validation, and test data.

class smartsolve.SupportVectorMachines(training_data, optimization_algorithm='GD', kernel='linear', learning_rate=0.0001, lam=0.0001, max_iteration=1000, threshold=1e-05, regularization_parameter=1, epsilon=0.0001, sigma=- 0.1)[source]

Bases: object

Support Vector Machines (SVM) classifier.

Parameters: - training_data: List of training data points in the form [(y, [x1, x2, …, xn]), …]. - optimization_algorithm: Optimization algorithm to use (‘GD’ for Gradient Descent,

‘SMO’ for Sequential Minimal Optimization).

  • kernel: Kernel function to use (‘linear’, ‘quadratic’, ‘gaussian’).

  • learning_rate: Learning rate for GD (default is 1e-4).

  • lam: Regularization parameter (default is 1e-4).

  • max_iteration: Maximum number of iterations for training (default is 1000).

  • threshold: Convergence threshold for GD (default is 1e-5).

  • regularization_parameter: Regularization parameter for SMO (default is 1).

  • epsilon: Convergence tolerance for SMO (default is 1e-4).

  • sigma: Sigma value for the Gaussian kernel (default is -0.1).

The training_data must have the structure: [(y1, [x11, x12, …, x1n]), (y2, [x21, x22, x2n]), …, (ym, [xm1, xm2, …, xmn])]

Methods: - train: Train the SVM model using the selected optimization algorithm. - predict: Make predictions on input data points after training.

Note: Call the ‘train’ method before making predictions.

roc_curve(training_data, validation_data, coefficients=None, bias=None, learning_rate=0.0001, positive_label=None, negative_label=None, max_iter=100, seed=42, norm='yes', num_iter=10, lower_bound=0.4, upper_bound=0.6)[source]

Generate Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curves and calculate Area Under the Curve (AUC) values.

Parameters:

  • training_data – Training data for logistic regression.

  • validation_data – Validation data for generating ROC curves.

  • coefficients – Initial coefficients for logistic regression (if None, they will be initialized).

  • bias – Initial bias for logistic regression (if None, it will be initialized).

  • learning_rate – Learning rate for logistic regression.

  • positive_label – Specify the positive label (default is the first unique label in data).

  • negative_label – Specify the negative label (default is the second unique label in data).

  • max_iter – Maximum number of iterations for logistic regression.

  • seed –

  • norm – Should the data before training process be normalized.

  • num_iter – Number of threshold values for ROC curve.

  • lower_bound – Lower bound for ROC curve threshold.

  • upper_bound – Upper bound for ROC curve threshold.

Returns:

List of ROC curve data as tuples (threshold, AUC).
